question:
Which of the following rulers is credited with the construction of Purana Quila in Delhi?

Higher Secondary 28/06/2023 (Shift - 2)
option_2: Qutub ud din and Iltutmish
option_3: Shah Jahan and Jahangir
option_4: Humayun and Sher Shah
solution:
• Purana Qila (Old Fort) is one of the oldest forts in Delhi.
  • It was originally begun by Humayun in 1533 CE as part of his city project named Dinpanah.
  • After Humayun was defeated, Sher Shah Suri captured Delhi and made major additions and modifications to the fort.
  • Sher Shah built several structures inside the fort, including the Qila-i-Kuhna Mosque.
  • The architecture of the fort reflects both Mughal and Afghan styles due to the contributions of both rulers.
  • Later, when Humayun regained power, he continued construction but died soon after falling from the steps of his library inside the fort.
  • Thus, both Humayun and Sher Shah Suri are credited for the construction and development of Purana Qila.

question:
The historical Sher-Shah Suri Marg runs between __________.

SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The historical Sher Shah Suri Marg is part of the Grand Trunk Road (GT Road), one of the oldest and longest roads in South Asia.
  • It was significantly rebuilt and expanded by Sher Shah Suri in the 16th century to improve communication and administration in his empire.
  • In modern terms, a stretch of this historical road is referred to as Sher Shah Suri Marg, especially in North India.
  • The route between Delhi and Amritsar is commonly associated with the name Sher Shah Suri Marg in contemporary usage.
  • This road passes through key cities such as Panipat, Karnal, Kurukshetra, Ambala, Ludhiana, and Jalandhar.
  • It has been a vital link for trade, military movement, and pilgrimage since ancient times.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Delhi and Amritsar.

question:
Humayun's Tomb situated in Delhi is built by ___________.

SSC CHSL 13/03/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Humayun's Tomb in Delhi is a major architectural monument and the first garden tomb in the Indian subcontinent.
  • It was commissioned by Bega Begum (also known as Haji Begum), the chief consort and widow of Emperor Humayun, in 1565 CE.
  • The construction was completed in 1572 CE, during the reign of Akbar, Humayun's son.
  • The architect of the tomb was Mirak Mirza Ghiyas, a Persian architect brought from the Safavid court.
  • The tomb is considered a precursor to the Taj Mahal and represents a blend of Persian and Indian architectural styles.
  • It was also the first structure to use red sandstone at such a grand scale in Mughal architecture.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Bega Begum.

question:
Mirza Kamran was the brother of which of the following Mughal emperors?

SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• Mirza Kamran was the younger half-brother of Mughal Emperor Humayun.
  • Both were sons of Babur, the founder of the Mughal Empire in India.
  • After Babur's death in 1530, Humayun became emperor, but Kamran did not accept his authority fully and ruled over Lahore and Kabul independently.
  • Mirza Kamran repeatedly rebelled against Humayun, creating internal conflicts that weakened the Mughal position in India.
  • During Humayun's exile, Kamran even tried to ally with Sher Shah Suri, further complicating matters.
  • Eventually, Kamran was captured and blinded by order of Humayun to prevent future rebellions.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Humayun.

question:
Which of the following pairs of 'Ruler - Ruling period' is correctly matched?

I. Sher Shah Suri - 1540-1545

II. Akbar - 1556-1605

SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
option_1: Neither I nor II
option_4: Both I and II
solution:
• Statement I: Sher Shah Suri – 1540–1545

    ✓ Correct. Sher Shah Suri defeated Humayun in the Battle of Kannauj (1540) and ruled the Sur Empire from 1540 to 1545 until his death in an accidental explosion at Kalinjar.

  • Statement II: Akbar – 1556–1605

    ✓ Correct. Akbar ascended the Mughal throne in 1556 after Humayun’s death and ruled until his own death in 1605. His reign lasted 49 years and marked the consolidation and expansion of the Mughal Empire.

  • Since both statements are correct, the correct answer is (d) Both I and II.

question:
Where is the tomb of Sher Shah Suri located?

SSC CHSL 17/03/2020 (Morning)
solution:
• The tomb of Sher Shah Suri is located in Sasaram, a town in the Rohtas district of Bihar.
  • It was built between 1540 and 1545 CE, during his own lifetime, and completed shortly after his death.
  • The tomb is situated in the middle of an artificial lake and is considered an architectural masterpiece of Afghan architecture in India.
  • It is constructed using red sandstone and features a large central dome, chhatris, and ornamental arches.
  • Sher Shah Suri died in 1545 CE due to a gunpowder explosion during the siege of Kalinjar fort.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Sasaram.

question: Who succeeded Babur as the Mughal emperor of India?
solution:
• Babur, the founder of the Mughal Empire in India, died in 1530 CE.
  • After his death, he was succeeded by his son Humayun as the second Mughal emperor.
  • Humayun's reign lasted from 1530 to 1540, and then again from 1555 to 1556, after regaining the throne from Sher Shah Suri’s successors.
  • Other options are incorrect chronologically:

    – Akbar was Humayun’s son and came to power in 1556.

    – Jahangir was Akbar’s son.

    – Aurangzeb was the son of Shah Jahan and ruled much later.

  • Therefore, the correct answer is Humayun.

question: Humayun’s biggest rival in North India who ultimately defeated him was:
option_4: Bahadur Shah of Gujarat
solution:
• Sher Shah Suri was the greatest rival of Humayun in North India.
  • Originally known as Farid Khan, he rose through the ranks to become a formidable Afghan ruler.
  • In the Battle of Chausa (1539) and the Battle of Kannauj (1540), Sher Shah decisively defeated Humayun.
  • After his defeat in 1540, Humayun went into exile for almost 15 years.
  • Sher Shah established the Sur Empire, ruling North India efficiently until his death in 1545.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Sher Shah Suri.

question: The decisive battle in which Sher Shah Suri defeated Humayun in 1540 was:
solution:
• The decisive battle in which Sher Shah Suri defeated Humayun in 1540 CE was the Battle of Kannauj, also known as the Battle of Bilgram.
  • This battle followed the earlier Battle of Chausa (1539), where Sher Shah had already defeated Humayun but did not capture Delhi.
  • In the Battle of Kannauj, Sher Shah decisively routed Humayun, forcing him into exile for the next 15 years.
  • After this victory, Sher Shah assumed control over the Mughal territories and founded the Sur Empire.
  • Other options are incorrect:

    – Battle of Khanwa (1527): Babur vs. Rana Sanga.

    – Battle of Panipat (1526): Babur vs. Ibrahim Lodi.

    – Battle of Ghaghra (1529): Babur vs. Afghans and Sultan of Bengal.

  • Therefore, the correct answer is Battle of Kannauj (Bilgram).

question: Before the Battle of Kannauj, Humayun had earlier been defeated by Sher Shah at:
solution:
• Before the Battle of Kannauj (1540), Humayun had already been defeated by Sher Shah Suri at the Battle of Chausa in 1539 CE.
  • The Battle of Chausa took place near the town of Chausa in Bihar, where Sher Shah launched a surprise attack.
  • Humayun’s army was caught off guard and suffered a devastating defeat.
  • After this battle, Sher Shah assumed the royal title of “Sher Shah” and declared himself the ruler.
  • This victory significantly weakened Humayun’s position and set the stage for his final defeat at Kannauj.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Chausa.

question: During his exile, Humayun took refuge at the court of which Persian ruler?
solution:
• After being defeated by Sher Shah Suri in 1540, Humayun went into exile for nearly 15 years.
  • During this period, he took refuge at the court of the Persian ruler Shah Tahmasp I, the Safavid emperor of Iran.
  • Shah Tahmasp treated Humayun honourably and provided him with military and political support, on the condition that Humayun adopt Shia Islam (at least nominally).
  • With Persian support, Humayun was later able to recapture Kandahar and Kabul, eventually returning to India and restoring Mughal rule in 1555.
  • Other options are incorrect:

    – Shah Abbas ruled much later (1588–1629).

    – Sultan Selim was an Ottoman ruler, not Persian.

    – Timur II was a Central Asian conqueror long before the Mughals.

  • Therefore, the correct answer is Shah Tahmasp.

question: The famous Mughal general Bairam Khan helped Humayun’s successor in:
solution:
• Bairam Khan was a trusted Mughal general and mentor to Akbar, the son and successor of Humayun.
  • After Humayun's death in 1556, the young Akbar (only 13 years old) ascended the throne.
  • At this critical juncture, Bairam Khan acted as Akbar's regent and took charge of military and administrative affairs.
  • One of his most significant contributions was defeating Hemu (a powerful Hindu general of the Sur Empire) in the Second Battle of Panipat (1556).
  • This victory was crucial in recovering Delhi and re-establishing Mughal authority in North India.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is recovering Delhi.

question: Which ruler offered Humayun asylum and military assistance during his exile?
option_1: Sultan Mahmud of Bengal
option_2: Shah Tahmasp of Persia
option_3: Bahadur Shah of Gujarat
option_4: Rana Udai Singh of Mewar
solution:
• After his defeat by Sher Shah Suri, Humayun went into exile in 1540 CE and sought support to regain his lost empire.
  • He approached Shah Tahmasp I, the Safavid ruler of Persia, who granted him asylum and promised military assistance.
  • In return, Humayun had to formally accept Shia Islam, though it was more a diplomatic gesture than deep religious conversion.
  • With the help of Persian troops, Humayun recaptured Kandahar and Kabul, and eventually regained control of Delhi in 1555 CE.
  • Other options are incorrect as none of those rulers offered him comparable refuge or aid.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Shah Tahmasp of Persia.

question: The Mughal Empire was restored by Humayun after he reconquered Delhi in:
solution:
• After being defeated by Sher Shah Suri in 1540, Humayun went into exile for about 15 years.
  • During this time, the Sur Empire ruled over much of North India.
  • After the death of Sher Shah and subsequent instability in the Sur dynasty, Humayun saw an opportunity to return.
  • With military assistance from Shah Tahmasp of Persia, Humayun successfully captured Kabul and Kandahar first.
  • He then marched into India and recaptured Delhi in 1555, thus restoring the Mughal Empire.
  • Unfortunately, Humayun died the following year in 1556 due to a fall from the stairs of his library.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is 1555.

question: Which city was taken by Humayun before he could reoccupy Delhi in 1555?
solution:
• Before Humayun could reoccupy Delhi in 1555, he first had to secure his base in Northwest India.
  • The first major city that Humayun captured during his return campaign was Lahore, which he took in February 1555.
  • After the victory at Lahore, Humayun’s forces moved southeast and captured Delhi and Agra later that year.
  • This reconquest marked the restoration of the Mughal Empire after a 15-year exile.
  • Other cities like Multan, Agra, and Patna were important but were either taken later or not directly involved in the final approach to Delhi.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Lahore.

question: How did Humayun die in 1556?
option_3: Fell from the stairs of his library
solution:
• Humayun, the second Mughal emperor, died in 1556 in a tragic accident.
  • While descending the stairs of his library (located at Dinpanah, later part of Purana Qila in Delhi), he slipped and fell down.
  • The accident happened as he was responding to the call for prayer (Azaan) and got entangled in his long robe.
  • He sustained severe head injuries and died a few days later, marking the end of his brief second reign.
  • This incident led to the immediate succession of his son Akbar to the Mughal throne.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Fell from the stairs of his library.

question: Humayun’s tomb in Delhi was built by:
solution:
• Humayun’s Tomb, located in Delhi, was the first garden tomb in the Indian subcontinent and a major example of Mughal architecture.
  • It was commissioned by Bega Begum, also known as Haji Begum, who was Humayun’s chief consort and widow.
  • Construction began in 1565 CE, nine years after Humayun’s death, and was completed in 1572 CE, during the reign of Emperor Akbar.
  • The architect was Mirak Mirza Ghiyas, a Persian architect brought specially for the project.
  • Though Hamida Banu Begum was Humayun’s wife and Akbar’s mother, she was not responsible for the tomb’s construction.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Bega Begum.

question: Which language did Humayun use in his court for administration and culture?
solution:
• The official language of administration and culture in Humayun's court was Persian.
  • Although the Mughals were of Turko-Mongol origin, Persian was considered a prestigious and refined language in the Islamic world.
  • Humayun was personally fluent in Turkish, Arabic, and Persian, but chose Persian for court use.
  • Persian was used extensively for official documents, correspondence, literature, poetry, and history writing.
  • The tradition of using Persian was continued by his successors like Akbar, Jahangir, and Shah Jahan.
  • Persian became the dominant cultural and administrative language of the Mughal Empire.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Persian.

question: Who wrote the historical account Humayun-nama?
solution:
• The Humayun-nama is a historical biography of Mughal Emperor Humayun.
  • It was written by Gulbadan Begum, who was Humayun’s half-sister and the daughter of Babur, the founder of the Mughal Empire.
  • She wrote it at the request of Akbar, to provide an authentic family account of Humayun’s life and the early Mughal court.
  • The text is unique because it provides a female perspective on Mughal history, written in simple Persian.
  • It gives valuable insight into the personal lives of the Mughal royal family, particularly Humayun’s struggles and exile.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Gulbadan Begum.

question: Humayun’s reign is often characterized by:
option_1: Constant success and stability
option_2: Territorial expansion into South India
option_3: Internal weaknesses and exile
solution:
• Humayun’s reign (1530–1540 & 1555–1556) is largely marked by instability, military defeats, and exile.
  • After ascending the throne in 1530, Humayun faced strong rivals like Sher Shah Suri, who ultimately defeated him in the Battle of Chausa (1539) and Battle of Kannauj (1540).
  • This forced Humayun into exile for nearly 15 years, during which the Sur Empire ruled much of northern India.
  • Though he regained the throne in 1555, his second reign lasted only about a year before his sudden death in 1556.
  • His rule lacked the administrative consolidation and military success that later defined Akbar's era.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is internal weaknesses and exile.

question: Who was the father of Akbar, the greatest Mughal ruler?
solution:
• Akbar, often regarded as the greatest Mughal emperor, was the son of Humayun, the second Mughal ruler.
  • Akbar was born in 1542 CE at Umerkot in present-day Pakistan during Humayun’s exile.
  • After Humayun's death in 1556, Akbar ascended the throne at the age of 13.
  • Bairam Khan, a loyal general of Humayun, acted as Akbar’s regent and mentor during his early reign.
  • Other options are incorrect:

    – Bairam Khan was not Akbar’s father, but his guardian.

    – Sher Shah Suri was Humayun’s enemy.

    – Jahangir was Akbar’s son, not father.

  • Therefore, the correct answer is Humayun.

question: Humayun divided his empire among his brothers, which ultimately led to:
option_4: Victory over Sher Shah
solution:
• Humayun, upon ascending the Mughal throne in 1530, chose to divide his empire among his brothers, including Kamran Mirza, Askari Mirza, and Hindal Mirza.
  • His intention was to maintain family unity and loyalty, but it had the opposite effect.
  • This division led to infighting, rivalry, and betrayal, especially by Kamran Mirza, who repeatedly acted against Humayun’s interests.
  • These internal conflicts weakened the central authority and made the empire vulnerable to external threats, particularly from Sher Shah Suri.
  • This disunity ultimately contributed to Humayun’s defeat and exile.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is political instability.

question: Which brother of Humayun rebelled against him and caused major setbacks?
solution:
• Kamran Mirza was the younger half-brother of Humayun and the governor of Kabul and Lahore.
  • After Babur’s death, Kamran refused to recognise Humayun’s authority and aimed to control large portions of the empire himself.
  • He rebelled multiple times against Humayun, often siding with external enemies like Sher Shah Suri.
  • His betrayals and lack of coordination with Humayun led to major military and political setbacks for the Mughal Empire.
  • Eventually, Humayun had Kamran captured and blinded to prevent further rebellion.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Kamran Mirza.

question: The Battle of Chausa (1539) resulted in:
option_1: Humayun’s first major victory
option_3: Humayun’s humiliating escape across the Ganges
option_4: Formation of Rajput alliance
solution:
• The Battle of Chausa was fought in 1539 CE between Humayun and Sher Shah Suri near Chausa in Bihar.
  • Sher Shah launched a surprise attack on Humayun’s camp, catching the Mughal army off guard.
  • Humayun suffered a crushing defeat, and many of his soldiers were killed or drowned while fleeing.
  • He barely escaped with his life by crossing the Ganges River using an inflated water bag (mashk), making it a humiliating retreat.
  • After this victory, Sher Shah assumed the royal title of “Sher Shah” and laid the foundation of the Sur Empire.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Humayun’s humiliating escape across the Ganges.

question: Sher Shah Suri assumed the royal title after defeating Humayun at:
solution:
• Sher Shah Suri assumed the royal title of "Sher Shah" after his decisive victory over Humayun in the Battle of Chausa in 1539 CE.
  • The battle took place near Chausa in Bihar, where Sher Shah launched a surprise attack on the Mughal forces.
  • After defeating Humayun, who barely escaped with his life, Sher Shah declared himself the sovereign ruler and adopted the regal title “Sher Shah”.
  • This victory laid the foundation of the Sur Empire, which would later be solidified with another win at Kannauj (1540).
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Chausa.

question: What was the political situation in India during Humayun’s exile?
option_2: Complete control by Rajputs
option_3: Afghan dominance under Sur dynasty
solution:
• During Humayun’s exile (1540–1555), Mughal rule had collapsed due to his defeat by Sher Shah Suri.
  • Sher Shah, an Afghan leader, established the Sur dynasty and took control over North India.
  • He implemented major administrative, military, and revenue reforms, strengthening Afghan rule.
  • After Sher Shah’s death in 1545, his successors ruled, but internal instability began to rise.
  • Despite succession struggles, the Afghans maintained dominance over the Indian political landscape during this time.
  • Humayun could only reclaim the throne in 1555, ending this phase of Afghan control.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Afghan dominance under Sur dynasty.

question: In return for Persian military help, what did Humayun have to cede to Shah Tahmasp?
solution:
• When Humayun sought military assistance from Shah Tahmasp I, the Safavid ruler of Persia, during his exile, Shah Tahmasp agreed to help.
  • In return, Humayun had to cede Kandahar — a strategically important city — to the Persians.
  • This deal was part of the diplomatic terms for the Persian military support that helped Humayun reconquer parts of his lost empire.
  • With this help, Humayun regained control of Kabul, Lahore, and eventually Delhi in 1555.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Kandahar.

question: Humayun regained Delhi in 1555 after defeating:
solution:
• Humayun regained the throne of Delhi in 1555 after defeating Sikandar Sur, a ruler of the Sur Dynasty.
  • After being ousted by Sher Shah Suri in 1540, Humayun lived in exile for about 15 years.
  • With the help of the Persian ruler Shah Tahmasp I, he reassembled his forces and launched a campaign to reclaim India.
  • The decisive battle was the Battle of Sirhind (1555) where Sikandar Sur was defeated, enabling Humayun to reoccupy Delhi.

question: What was the biggest lesson learned by Akbar from Humayun’s rule?
option_2: Need for religious orthodoxy
option_3: Avoiding division of empire among brothers
solution:
• The biggest lesson Akbar learned from Humayun's rule was the danger of dividing the empire among brothers, which led to internal conflict and weakened central authority.
  • Humayun faced many difficulties due to succession disputes and rivalry among nobles and relatives.
  • Akbar ensured centralised control and undivided succession by not dividing the empire among his sons and by establishing clear rules for succession.
  • This helped maintain stability and continuity in the Mughal administration after his reign.

question: The Humayun-Nama is unique because:
option_1: It’s the only text in Arabic
option_2: It was written by a female member of the royal family
option_3: It focuses only on wars
option_4: It is the first autobiography of a Mughal
solution:
• The Humayun-Nama is unique because it was written by a female member of the royal family, Gulbadan Begum, the daughter of Babur and sister of Humayun.
  • This makes it a rare and valuable account, offering a woman's perspective on life in the Mughal court during the early years of the empire.
  • The work is written in Persian, and although it covers political and military events, it also includes personal anecdotes, court customs, and familial relationships, making it a rich historical source.
  • It was commissioned by Akbar, who wanted an authentic account of his father's life.
